text: Hong Kong's just had one of its biggest
ever protests in history organizers say
more than a million people took to the
streets one in seven of the population
if the numbers are right which is simply
huge people are really worried about a
proposed law that would allow
extradition to mainland China critics
have pointed out that businesspeople and
expats in Hong Kong or even tourists
going through this could potentially in
theory be extradited to mainland China
so the law is quite complicated but let
me try and break it down for you the law
would allow Hong Kong to extradite
people to other countries it doesn't
have agreements with including mainland
China the government says there are
certain safeguards so only people
accused of serious and criminal offences
will be extradited people accused of
political or religious crimes won't be
extradited the government also says that
each decision to extradite will be
approved by a judge but the truth is
even some judges have spoken out against
the laws and said they're concerned this
will affect their independence Hong
Kong's a small territory in mainland
China and it is part of China although
it has its own legal system its own
judiciary and its own borders and a lot
of these systems were inherited from its
time as a British colony but China
watchers what happens in Hong Kong
really closely it's because China's
really protective of its territory and
it probably views Hong Kong as a bit of
a troublemaker where people are
demanding democracy demanding more
autonomy and China just sees that as
sort of threatening Hong Kong's no
stranger to protests in fact it's quite
famous for them
you had the umbrella protests back in
2014 and Hong Kong often has
pro-democracy protests protests there
have actually led to changes in
government policy in the past but it has
become less common in recent years and a
lot of people think that's because the
Beijing government has taken a harder
stance now the protests aren't being led
by any particular one person a number of
pro-democracy and human rights groups
have been organizing the protests on the
day of the historic turnout at the
protest and the term Hong Kong was
censored on Chinese social media the
Chinese government has been issuing
statements telling Western countries not
to get involved saying mind your own
business essentially they've also said
that the fears are overblown Kerry lambs
the chief executive of Hong Kong which
means she leads the territory and
people feel that even though she's
competent ultimately she's answering to
Beijing there have been protests in at
least 29 different cities including
London against the treaty as well and I
way way the Chinese artist actually
showed up to that he said he wanted to
support Hong Kong people we've spoken
out for him back when he'd been detained
in China he of course was detained under
tax related offences even though he said
they were political at the time the main
slogan from these protests has been fan
song songs which are three words that
basically translate to opposed to
sending to China people have pointed out
the phrase song song also sounds exactly
like another phrase which means seeing
off a dead relative and they say that's
quite apt because many people argue that
this bill would need the death of Hong
Kong
